study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the impact of nasal intermittent positive pressure ventilation (NIPPV) versus continuous positive airway pressure (CPAP) on apnea of prematurity (AOP) in preterm neonates.
results_summary: The study found no difference in AOP frequency per hour between NIPPV and CPAP, but a post hoc analysis showed lower odds of developing any AOP with NIPPV. However, the evidence quality was insufficient for definitive recommendations.
population_specificity: Preterm neonates with apnea of prematurity (AOP).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the relationship between mask-related side effects (MRSEs) and CPAP non-adherence or residual excessive sleepiness in long-term CPAP-treated patients.
results_summary: The study found that leak-related side effects were the most prevalent MRSEs, but patient-reported leaks could not be predicted by CPAP-reported leaks. MRSEs were independently associated with CPAP non-adherence and residual excessive sleepiness, suggesting a need for complementary monitoring approaches.
population_specificity: Apneic adults undergoing at least 3 months of CPAP therapy with unrestricted mask access (72.2% male, median age 67 years).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the association of surgical treatments for OSA with clinically relevant outcomes (cardiovascular, neurological, and endocrine complications) compared to CPAP alone.
results_summary: Soft tissue surgery for OSA was associated with lower rates of cardiovascular, neurological, and endocrine complications compared to CPAP alone, while skeletal surgery showed no significant differences. The findings suggest surgery may benefit high-risk CPAP nonadherent patients.
population_specificity: Working insured US adults aged 40-89 diagnosed with OSA and prescribed CPAP, with at least 3 years of data.
study_duration: Median follow-up of 4.47 years (interquartile range, 3-8 years)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the feasibility of a large-scale trial and update an economic model to determine the cost-effectiveness and value of further research on prehospital Continuous Positive Airway Pressure (CPAP) compared to standard oxygen therapy for acute respiratory failure.
results_summary: The study found that recruitment rates were below target, CPAP was fully delivered to 74% of participants, and 30-day mortality was 27.3%. The economic evaluation suggested uncertainty about CPAP's cost-effectiveness, and limited compliance and difficulty identifying patients who could benefit indicated CPAP was unlikely to significantly reduce mortality.
population_specificity: Adults with respiratory distress and peripheral oxygen saturations below British Thoracic Society target levels, excluding those with limited potential to benefit or contraindications to CPAP.
effective_dosage: Not specified (CPAP delivered via O-Two system).
study_duration: Intervention administered prehospital; follow-up lasted 30 days.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the effects of noninvasive positive-pressure ventilation (NPPV) on cardiac function and survival in patients with sleep-disordered breathing and chronic congestive heart failure.
results_summary: Short-term ASV treatment (3-6 months) significantly improved event-free survival and cardiac function in HFrEF + CSA patients, but prolonged treatment showed no effect on all-cause mortality and may have negative effects.
population_specificity: Heart failure patients with reduced ejection fraction and sleep-disordered breathing (HFrEF + SDB), particularly those with central sleep apnea (CSA).
study_duration: 3-6 months (short-term), prolonged treatment duration not specified

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the effect of CPAP treatment on plasma fibrinogen levels in patients with obstructive sleep apnea (OSA).
results_summary: The meta-analysis found that long-term CPAP therapy (≥1 month) with good compliance (≥4 h/night) significantly reduced plasma fibrinogen levels in OSA patients, while short-term therapy and poor compliance did not show significant effects.
population_specificity: Patients with obstructive sleep apnea (OSA).
study_duration: Long-term (≥1 month) and short-term (<1 month) subgroups.

study_goal: The study aimed to evaluate the safety, tolerability, and preliminary efficacy of BIO101 (not Continuous Positive Airway Pressure) in preventing respiratory deterioration in hospitalized COVID-19 patients.
results_summary: The abstract does not provide specific results regarding Continuous Positive Airway Pressure, as the study focuses on BIO101.
population_specificity: Hospitalized COVID-19 patients aged 45+ with pneumonia and respiratory decompensation.
effective_dosage: Not applicable (study focused on BIO101, not CPAP).
study_duration: Up to 28 days or until a clinical endpoint was reached.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of supplemental oxygen therapy and CPAP on patients with obstructive sleep apnea (OSA).
results_summary: CPAP was found to be clinically effective for treating OSA, while supplemental oxygen therapy showed promise in improving nocturnal hypoxia and depression symptoms when CPAP was not tolerated. No significant difference was found in improving nocturnal oxygen saturation between the two treatments.
population_specificity: Patients with obstructive sleep apnea (OSA).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether changes in ICAM-1 levels following CPAP treatment were associated with improvements in sleepiness and blood pressure in adults with obstructive sleep apnea.
results_summary: The study found no significant association between changes in ICAM-1 levels and changes in sleepiness or blood pressure measures after 4 months of CPAP treatment. Future research should explore other potential biomarkers mediating these outcomes.
population_specificity: Adults with newly diagnosed obstructive sleep apnea (83% men, mean BMI 31.5 ± 4.2 kg/m²).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the metabolic effects of CPAP versus MAD versus no treatment in patients with mild OSA over 6 and 12 months.
results_summary: CPAP was more effective than MAD in reducing total cholesterol and LDL-c over 12 months, despite lower adherence compared to MAD. Both treatments reduced AHI compared to the control group.
population_specificity: Patients with mild OSA, aged 18-65, BMI < 35 kg/m², 54% male.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to examine the association of CPAP use (as a bridge to invasive mechanical ventilation or as a ceiling-of-care) with mortality in COVID-19 patients.
results_summary: CPAP showed a favorable therapeutic alternative to early intubation in patients without a ceiling-of-care, with 75% recovering without needing IMV. However, CPAP offered little survival benefit for patients with a ceiling-of-care compared to oxygen therapy alone.
population_specificity: Adults with SARS-CoV-2 swab-positive results admitted to Calderdale and Huddersfield NHS Foundation Trust (UK) between March 10 and April 19, 2020.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to analyze the characteristics and early risk factors for mortality associated with noninvasive ventilation (NIV), including Continuous Positive Airway Pressure (CPAP), in critically ill children.
results_summary: CPAP was used more frequently in younger patients (33.7%) than older ones (9.7%). Risk factors for mortality included immunodeficiency, cerebral palsy, apneas on admission, tachypnea 6 hours after NIV onset, and NIV failure.
population_specificity: Critically ill children aged 1 month to 18 years requiring NIV.
study_duration: Data collected during the first 12 hours of admission; study duration was 2 years.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of Continuous Positive Airway Pressure (CPAP) in improving obstructive sleep apnea (OSA) and reducing seizures in patients with epilepsy.
results_summary: CPAP therapy was found to be the most effective non-pharmacological method for improving OSA and reducing seizures in patients with epilepsy. The abstract highlights its efficacy but notes a lack of large-scale randomized controlled trials to further validate these findings.
population_specificity: Patients with epilepsy and comorbid sleep disorders, particularly obstructive sleep apnea (OSA).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether treating obstructive sleep apnea (OSA) with continuous positive airway pressure (CPAP) improves depressive symptoms and leads to remission of clinical depression in patients with comorbid OSA and depression.
results_summary: CPAP treatment significantly reduced depressive symptoms and sleepiness compared to waitlist controls, and a significant reduction in the proportion of participants meeting criteria for clinical depression was observed in the CPAP group.
population_specificity: 121 untreated OSA patients with comorbid clinical depression.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of CPAP in reducing recurrent vascular events and mortality in poststroke obstructive sleep apnea (OSA) and propose improvements for future trials.
results_summary: The study found mixed results regarding CPAP's effectiveness in poststroke OSA, with prior trials being underpowered and inconclusive. It suggests intervention, population, and timing changes to improve future research.
population_specificity: Stroke patients with obstructive sleep apnea (OSA).
effective_dosage: Not specified (focus on usage ≥4 hours per night).
study_duration: Not specified (proposes early initiation within 48 hours of stroke and long-term follow-up).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effect of CPAP on anxiety in coronary artery disease (CAD) patients with nonsleepy obstructive sleep apnea (OSA) following revascularization.
results_summary: CPAP had no significant effect on anxiety scores in the intention-to-treat analysis. However, adherent CPAP users (≥2.8 h/day) showed a significant increase in anxiety scores after three months and one year, while non-adherent or no-CPAP groups showed a decline.
population_specificity: Revascularized CAD patients with nonsleepy OSA (apnea-hypopnea index ≥15/h, Epworth Sleepiness Scale score <10).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to describe the treatments offered to children with severe acute bronchiolitis in a Spanish PICU and analyze changes in management after the 2014 AAP guideline publication.
results_summary: Continuous positive airway pressure (CPAP) and bi-level positive airway pressure were used less during 2015-2016 compared to the previous period. Overall, 83% of patients received non-invasive ventilation or high-flow oxygen therapy (HFOT).
population_specificity: Children admitted to a Spanish tertiary pediatric intensive care unit (PICU) with severe acute bronchiolitis (median age 1.8 months).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the role of hypoglossal nerve stimulation (HNS) as an alternative treatment for CPAP-intolerant obstructive sleep apnea (OSA) patients and discuss post-implant management strategies.
results_summary: The study highlights HNS as a well-established, effective alternative for CPAP-intolerant OSA patients, with robust safety, efficacy, and durability data from multiple trials and registries. However, it emphasizes the need for standardized post-implant management to optimize long-term outcomes, particularly for patients with partial responses.
population_specificity: CPAP-intolerant obstructive sleep apnea (OSA) patients.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the efficacy of Continuous Positive Airway Pressure (CPAP) as a sleep intervention for individuals with Mild Cognitive Impairment (MCI) or mild Alzheimer's Disease (AD) dementia, particularly those with Obstructive Sleep Apnoea.
results_summary: CPAP demonstrated efficacy in participants with Obstructive Sleep Apnoea, though the abstract does not specify the magnitude of improvement. The study highlights a lack of extensive evidence for other sleep interventions in this population.
population_specificity: Individuals with Mild Cognitive Impairment (MCI) or mild Alzheimer's Disease (AD) dementia, particularly those with Obstructive Sleep Apnoea.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effectiveness of Helmet CPAP versus HFNC in reducing the need for invasive mechanical ventilation in COVID-19 patients with hypoxaemia.
results_summary: The study hypothesizes that Helmet CPAP may reduce the need for intubation compared to HFNC, but direct comparative results are pending as the trial was planned and not yet completed at the time of the abstract.
population_specificity: COVID-19 patients with hypoxaemia despite conventional low-flow oxygen therapy, treated at an intermediate-level COVID-19 cohort ward in Helsingborg Hospital, Sweden.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate pressure stability and imposed work of breathing (iWOB) of five CPAP systems used in low-resource settings to treat respiratory distress in neonates.
results_summary: The study found significant differences in resistance and iWOB among the five CPAP systems, with three devices showing lower resistance (<0.4) and two showing higher resistance (>1.0). The available literature does not indicate these differences affect clinical outcomes.
population_specificity: Preterm and term neonates (simulated infant sizes: 2.5 kg, 4.0 kg, 5.5 kg).
effective_dosage: Pressures generated at the bottle: 0, 3, 5, and 7 cm H2O.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether sustained lung inflation (SLI) followed by nasal CPAP reduces the need for invasive mechanical ventilation (IMV) in preterm infants compared to nasal CPAP alone.
results_summary: SLI did not significantly reduce the need for IMV in the overall study population but showed efficacy in subgroups of sicker infants (those with clinical eligibility criteria) and smaller babies (gestational age <30 weeks). The study concluded that SLI was not harmful.
population_specificity: Preterm infants with gestational age ≥27 and ≤32 weeks.
effective_dosage: SLI at 20 cmH2O for 15 seconds followed by nasal CPAP at 5 cmH2O.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine regional ventilation characteristics during non-invasive ventilation (NIV) in stable preterm infants and explore the relationship between ventilation homogeneity and respiratory status indicators.
results_summary: Ventilation was greater in the right lung (mean 69.1%) and favored the non-dependent lung, with ventilation inhomogeneity associated with worse oxygenation. High breath-by-breath variability in regional ventilation patterns was observed during NIV.
population_specificity: Forty stable preterm infants born <30 weeks of gestation receiving either continuous positive airway pressure (n=32) or high-flow nasal cannulae (n=8).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the long-term effect of CPAP on blood pressure in patients with obstructive sleep apnea (OSA) and resistant hypertension.
results_summary: Good adherence to long-term CPAP treatment significantly reduced 24-hour blood pressure, particularly during the night, and decreased the need for antihypertensive medications. A positive correlation was found between CPAP use duration and systolic blood pressure reduction.
population_specificity: Patients diagnosed with both OSA (AHI ≥15) and resistant hypertension.
effective_dosage: CPAP use of at least 4 hours per night (defined as good adherence).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to describe the use and efficacy of alternative CPAP devices in COVID-19 patients with respiratory failure.
results_summary: Alternative CPAP improved oxygenation parameters in patients, with a progressive increase in saturation (94% to 98-99%) and a statistically significant improvement in oxygen saturation/inspired oxygen fraction (p = 0.040). However, changes in respiratory frequency were not significant (p = 0.423).
population_specificity: 23 COVID-19 patients with respiratory failure admitted to IFEMA Field Hospital.
study_duration: Measurements taken at 30 and 60 minutes after mask application.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to validate the Saturation Oxygen Pressure Index (SOPI) as a non-invasive tool for monitoring respiratory distress in neonates on CPAP and determine its correlation with A-aDO2.
results_summary: The study found a significant positive correlation (82.7%) between SOPI and A-aDO2, with SOPI values of 1.52, 1.57, and 1.6 predicting A-aDO2 values of 70, 85, and 100, respectively, with high sensitivity and specificity.
population_specificity: 126 neonates with respiratory distress treated with CPAP.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the efficacy and safety of high-flow nasal cannula (HFNC) against nasal continuous positive airway pressure (NCPAP) or nasal intermittent positive-pressure ventilation (NIPPV) after extubation in preterm infants.
results_summary: The study found that HFNC had a significantly higher rate of treatment failure (31%) compared to NCPAP/NIPPV (16%). Factors associated with HFNC failure included histologic chorioamnionitis, treated patent ductus arteriosus, and younger corrected gestational age.
population_specificity: Preterm infants born at <34 weeks who needed noninvasive ventilation after extubation.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the potential therapeutic role of adjuvant Hemoperfusion (HP) in COVID-19 patients with severe pneumonia requiring continuous positive airway pressure.
results_summary: The study found that patients treated with HP showed better clinical outcomes, including higher survival rates and reduced need for intubation, compared to controls. Respiratory function remained stable in treated patients, and inflammatory markers decreased more significantly in the HP group.
population_specificity: 9 consecutive patients hospitalized in a COVID Intensive Care Unit with severe pneumonia requiring continuous positive airway pressure.
effective_dosage: 2 consecutive sessions of HP using CytoSorb cartridge.
study_duration: HP was started 6-7 days after hospital admission.

study_goal: To evaluate the effects of CPAP therapy on corneal endothelial morphometry and pachymetry in patients with obstructive sleep apnea-hypopnea syndrome (OSAHS).
results_summary: CPAP treatment improved corneal polymegathism (reduced CV) and pleomorphism (increased %Hex), with post-CPAP values resembling those of healthy controls. Greater improvement in polymegathism correlated with longer treatment duration and higher pre-CPAP NREM sleep percentage.
population_specificity: 27 patients recently diagnosed with OSAHS (mean age 54.2 ± 11.8 years).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to describe the clinical course, treatment, and outcomes of COVID-19 pneumonia patients, with a focus on oxygen delivery and ventilator support, including CPAP/NIV.
results_summary: CPAP/NIV showed mixed outcomes: high mortality (88.9%) in DNI patients, 57.1% NIV failure in non-DNI patients, but 96.3% survival in those who did not require mechanical ventilation.
population_specificity: 310 consecutive COVID-19 pneumonia patients admitted to an emergency room in Lombardy, Italy.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the impact of early surfactant administration on CPAP failure rates and clinical outcomes in very preterm infants with respiratory distress syndrome.
results_summary: Early surfactant administration reduced CPAP failure rates, with 100% of infants in the surfactant group receiving surfactant compared to 49% in the control group, and was associated with lower morbidity and mortality.
population_specificity: Very preterm infants (<32 weeks) with respiratory distress syndrome, initially managed on CPAP.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to summarize key aspects of bilevel PAP therapies, including CPAP, for treating sleep-related breathing disorders and central sleep apnea syndromes.
results_summary: The abstract highlights that CPAP and bilevel PAP therapies were developed to address obstructive sleep apnea and complex sleep-related breathing disorders, with advanced modes of NIV addressing broader cardiorespiratory pathophysiology.
population_specificity: Patients with obstructive sleep apnea, sleep-related hypoventilation disorders, treatment-emergent central sleep apnea, and central sleep apnea syndromes.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate predictors of 28-day mortality in COVID-19 patients, including the impact of Continuous Positive Airway Pressure (CPAP) treatment.
results_summary: The study found that the need for CPAP/NIV within the first 24 hours was a significant risk factor for 28-day mortality (OR 8.38). CPAP was used in 39% of patients, but its efficacy was not directly compared to other treatments.
population_specificity: COVID-19 patients admitted to the main hospital of Bergamo, Italy, during the peak of the outbreak (February 23 to March 14, 2020), predominantly male (72.4%) with a mean age of 66±15 years.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effectiveness of CPAP versus MAD in treating severe OSA patients with mandibular retrognathia.
results_summary: CPAP was superior to MAD in improving polysomnographic outcomes and Snore Scale scores, but MAD had higher compliance. Both treatments showed similar effectiveness in ESS and SAS scores. MAD was more effective in OSA patients with mandibular retrognathia than those without.
population_specificity: Severe OSA patients with mandibular retrognathia (ANB > 4.7° and SNB < 76.2°).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effects of CPAP treatment on glycaemic control and insulin resistance in patients with type 2 diabetes and obstructive sleep apnoea.
results_summary: CPAP significantly improved glycaemic control and insulin resistance, as evidenced by reduced HbA1c levels, fasting glucose levels, and HOMA-IR values, along with lowered systolic and diastolic blood pressure.
population_specificity: Patients with type 2 diabetes and obstructive sleep apnoea (691 participants across 7 trials).

study_goal: To compare immediate cessation versus stepwise pressure reduction of NCPAP on therapy duration in preterm infants.
results_summary: No difference in total NCPAP days between groups, but gradual weaning reduced failure rates at first discontinuation attempt, especially in infants 23-27 weeks gestational age.
population_specificity: Preterm infants (23-30 weeks gestational age).
effective_dosage: Stepwise pressure wean to 3 cm H2O.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate whether depression, anxiety, and stress symptoms before treatment affect the effectiveness of cognitive behavioral therapy for insomnia (CBTi) in patients with comorbid insomnia and sleep apnea (COMISA).
results_summary: The study found that CBTi improved insomnia symptoms in patients with COMISA, regardless of the severity of depression, anxiety, or stress symptoms before treatment. No evidence suggested that these comorbid symptoms impaired CBTi's effectiveness.
population_specificity: 145 patients with comorbid insomnia and sleep apnea (insomnia per ICSD-3 criteria and AHI ≥ 15 events/h).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether CPAP treatment reduces the incidence of reflux events in patients with obstructive sleep apnea (OSA).
results_summary: The meta-analysis found that CPAP treatment significantly reduced reflux events, with notable improvements in percentage time pH < 4, longest reflux duration, number of reflux events, DeMeester score, RDQ score, and RSI. Subgroup analysis indicated greater symptom improvement with longer treatment duration.
population_specificity: Patients with obstructive sleep apnea (OSA) and gastroesophageal reflux disease (GERD).
study_duration: Not specified (subgroup analysis suggests longer durations yield better results)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate how upper airway anatomy influences CPAP titration levels in patients with obstructive sleep apnea (OSA).
results_summary: The study found significant correlations between CPAP titration levels and upper airway length, distance from mandibular plane to hyoid bone, and neck circumference. BMI and upper airway length were independently associated with CPAP titration levels, suggesting these factors should be considered for improving CPAP compliance.
population_specificity: 157 subjects (134 males, 23 females) under investigation for OSA via polysomnography and CT scan.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether adding intranasal steroids (fluticasone furoate) to CPAP therapy reduces nasal symptoms and improves compliance in patients with obstructive sleep apnea (OSA).
results_summary: The study found that intranasal steroids significantly improved CPAP compliance and reduced rhinorrhea and congestion symptoms after 90 days, though no difference was observed at 30 days.
population_specificity: 83 patients with obstructive sleep apnea (OSA) receiving CPAP therapy.
effective_dosage: Fluticasone furoate nasal spray 55 μg (frequency not specified).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effect of CPAP on markers of arterial stiffness (PWV and Aix) in patients with obstructive sleep apnea (OSA).
results_summary: CPAP significantly improved arterial stiffness by reducing pulse wave velocity (PWV) but did not significantly affect augmentation index (Aix). The analysis included 9 randomized trials with moderate risk of bias.
population_specificity: Patients with obstructive sleep apnea (OSA).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the acute and long-term effects of neonatal exposure to Continuous Positive Airway Pressure (CPAP) on lung structure and function using animal models.
results_summary: CPAP improves lung function, causes less lung injury compared to mechanical ventilation, and does not disrupt alveolar development. However, CPAP may increase airway reactivity, and combining it with surfactant administration further enhances respiratory outcomes.
population_specificity: Newborn animal models (large and small animals).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the role of high-flow nasal cannula (HFNC) in COVID-19 patients after failure of Continuous Positive Airway Pressure (CPAP) or non-invasive mechanical ventilation (NIV).
results_summary: The study found that CPAP or NIV were uncomfortable and required significant man-machine cooperation, leading to failure in some patients. HFNC was successfully used in selected COVID-19 patients with ARDS after CPAP/NIV failure.
population_specificity: Five patients with COVID-19-related ARDS.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the relationship between obstructive sleep apnea (OSA) and arterial stiffness, focusing on the cardio-ankle vascular index (CAVI), and how CPAP treatment affects CAVI.
results_summary: The study found that CPAP treatment for OSA can reduce the CAVI, indicating a potential reduction in arterial stiffness and atherosclerosis risk. Several studies support CPAP's effectiveness in improving arterial health in OSA patients.
population_specificity: Patients with obstructive sleep apnea (OSA).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the procedural and clinical outcomes of introducing minimally invasive surfactant therapy (MIST) in neonatal intensive care units.
results_summary: MIST was successfully introduced in neonatal units with limited prior experience, and premedication with atropine reduced bradycardia incidence. Success rates improved when performed by clinicians skilled in endotracheal intubation.
population_specificity: Preterm infants in two tertiary Australian neonatal intensive care units (median gestation 30 weeks).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effect of CPAP on the need for intermittent positive pressure ventilation (IPPV) and associated morbidity in preterm infants with respiratory distress.
results_summary: CPAP reduced the risk of treatment failure (death or use of assisted ventilation) but was associated with an increased rate of pneumothorax compared to spontaneous breathing with supplemental oxygen. The applicability of results to current practice is unclear due to the age of most trials.
population_specificity: Preterm infants with respiratory distress.

study_goal: To determine if early initiation of CPAP reduces mortality and the need for intermittent positive-pressure ventilation in preterm infants with respiratory distress.
results_summary: The study found very low-certainty evidence on whether early CPAP affects the need for ventilation or mortality, with uncertain effects on air leak (pneumothorax). No significant adverse effects were reported, but long-term outcomes were not assessed.
population_specificity: Preterm infants in respiratory distress.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the characteristics of COVID-19 patients diagnosed with pulmonary embolism (PE), including the use of Continuous Positive Airway Pressure (CPAP) in their treatment.
results_summary: Among 15 COVID-19 patients with PE, 47% required CPAP, with 13% of those subsequently requiring intubation. The study did not focus on CPAP's efficacy but noted its use in severe cases.
population_specificity: COVID-19 patients admitted between March and April 2020, diagnosed with PE (median age 58, 87% male).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the feasibility and outcomes of using Continuous Positive Airway Pressure (CPAP) in a non-ICU setting for patients with acute respiratory failure during a COVID-19 surge.
results_summary: CPAP was initiated in 49 patients, with 38% recovering without intubation. Intubation was required in 51% of cases, while poor tolerance or death occurred in 16%.
population_specificity: Hypoxemic patients with respiratory failure or inability to maintain SpO2 > 90% despite high-flow oxygen, predominantly male (73%) with a median age of 65.
study_duration: Median duration of CPAP was 3 days (IQR = 1-5).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the relationship between the severity of hypoxic acute respiratory failure (hARF) and clinical outcomes, including the use of continuous positive airway pressure (CPAP), in hospitalized COVID-19 patients.
results_summary: The study found that the severity of hARF, as measured by PaO2/FiO2 ratio, was independently associated with a threefold increase in in-hospital mortality. CPAP was used as part of the treatment, but its specific efficacy was not detailed beyond its inclusion in secondary outcomes.
population_specificity: Hospitalized adult patients with virologically confirmed COVID-19 in three academic hospitals in Milan, Italy.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether Continuous Positive Airway Pressure (CPAP) mitigates ventilator-induced lung injury in severe acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS) patients on venovenous extracorporeal membrane oxygenation (VV-ECMO), compared to pressure-controlled ventilation.
results_summary: The study found a linear relationship between driving pressure changes and plasma biomarkers of lung injury, suggesting that reducing driving pressure to zero (via CPAP) may offer more protective ventilation for ARDS patients on VV-ECMO, though clinical outcomes require further validation.
population_specificity: Ten patients with severe ARDS supported on VV-ECMO.
effective_dosage: Continuous Positive Airway Pressure (specific pressure not detailed) administered for 2 hours.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the effects of CPAP treatment on cognitive trajectory and Alzheimer's disease biomarkers in patients with obstructive sleep apnea (OSA).
results_summary: The review found that CPAP treatment may influence Alzheimer's disease biomarkers and cognitive outcomes in OSA patients, though further studies are needed to confirm these effects and establish preventive strategies for Alzheimer's disease.
population_specificity: Elderly and adult patients with obstructive sleep apnea (OSA).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to summarize the definition, epidemiology, mechanisms, clinical characteristics, and treatment of Treatment-emergent central sleep apnea (TECSA) during Continuous Positive Airway Pressure (CPAP) therapy.
results_summary: TECSA may resolve spontaneously with ongoing CPAP treatment in some patients, but persists in others, requiring alternative therapies like adaptive servo-ventilation. The prevalence and mechanisms of TECSA vary widely, indicating a need for further research.
population_specificity: Patients with Treatment-emergent central sleep apnea (TECSA) during CPAP therapy for obstructive sleep apnea.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether CPAP treatment reduces daytime resting heart rate in individuals with OSA and prediabetes.
results_summary: CPAP treatment reduced daytime resting heart rate by 4.1 beats/min compared to placebo, with statistically significant results. The study suggests CPAP may have cardiovascular benefits in this population.
population_specificity: 39 participants with obstructive sleep apnea (OSA) and prediabetes.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare two different PEEP levels (6-8 cmH2O vs. 4-6 cmH2O) during nasal CPAP treatment in preterm infants to determine the optimal level for treating respiratory distress syndrome.
results_summary: The abstract does not provide specific results but indicates that the optimum PEEP level for treating respiratory distress syndrome in preterm infants is unknown, as previous trials used a wide range of PEEP levels (4-8 cmH2O). The study is designed to address this gap.
population_specificity: Preterm infants born at 26+0-29+6 gestational weeks.
effective_dosage: Two PEEP levels: 6-8 cmH2O and 4-6 cmH2O.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of supraglottic airway devices for surfactant delivery as an alternative to CPAP or endotracheal tube administration in infants with respiratory distress syndrome.
results_summary: The study found that surfactant administration via supraglottic airway devices had a high success rate and may reduce the need for subsequent intubation compared to CPAP or endotracheal tube delivery, though existing RCTs are limited in sample size and heterogeneity.
population_specificity: Infants with respiratory distress syndrome, primarily in tertiary care settings.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether continuous positive airway pressure (CPAP) therapy improves erectile dysfunction (ED) symptoms in patients with obstructive sleep apnoea (OSA).
results_summary: The study found that CPAP therapy significantly improved ED symptoms in OSA patients based on IIEF-5 scores, though heterogeneity among studies and limited sample size warrant further research.
population_specificity: 206 male patients with erectile dysfunction and obstructive sleep apnoea.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to describe real-life ASV settings and associated minute-ventilations for different ASV devices, and assess hyperventilation risks in patients with sleep-disordered breathing.
results_summary: The study found that real-life ASV settings are influenced by baseline and follow-up variables, with cardiological factors remaining clinically significant. It highlighted a hyperventilation risk across patient clusters, suggesting potential benefits of MV-telemonitoring for safety.
population_specificity: Patients on ASV treatment for at least 1 year, primarily male (87.57%), with conditions like OSA, CSA, or TECSA.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to examine changes in catecholamine levels and blood pressure in response to CPAP treatment in patients with obstructive sleep apnea (OSA).
results_summary: The meta-analysis found conflicting impacts of CPAP treatment on catecholamine levels and blood pressure, with results from 38 studies (14 RCTs and 24 PCS) analyzed. The study used standardized mean difference (SMD) for catecholamines and mean difference (MD) for systolic and diastolic blood pressure.
population_specificity: Patients with obstructive sleep apnea (OSA), mean age 41-62 years, BMI 27.2-35.1 kg/m².

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of CPAP, a mandibular advancement device (MAD), and no treatment on blood pressure and endothelial function in individuals with mild obstructive sleep apnea over 6 and 12 months.
results_summary: CPAP and MAD reduced apnea-hypopnea indexes compared to no treatment, but neither improved blood pressure or endothelial function after 1 year, even in patients with effective treatment adherence. CPAP showed higher blood oxygen levels than MAD, but MAD had better treatment adherence and adaptation rates.
population_specificity: Individuals aged 18-65 with mild obstructive sleep apnea (AHI < 5 events/h) and BMI ≤ 35 kg/m².

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether CPAP treatment improves moderate to vigorous physical activity levels in individuals with obstructive sleep apnea and co-occurring cardiovascular disease.
results_summary: The CPAP group reported significantly more physical activity (20% higher moderate activities), less limitation in physical activity, and more participants meeting recommended activity levels compared to the usual care group.
population_specificity: Individuals aged 45-75 with confirmed cardiovascular disease and obstructive sleep apnea.

study_goal: The researchers compared the effectiveness of upper airway stimulation (UAS) to continuous positive airway pressure (CPAP) for treating moderate to severe obstructive sleep apnea (OSA) in patients who failed CPAP therapy.
results_summary: The study found that UAS showed favorable success rates and low morbidity compared to traditional surgical treatments for OSA, though concerns remain about narrow candidacy criteria and long-term durability. CPAP was not directly evaluated in this study, but UAS was presented as an alternative for CPAP-resistant cases.
population_specificity: Patients with moderate to severe OSA who failed CPAP therapy, particularly those with lymphoid and muscular tongue base hypertrophy.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effectiveness of two oral appliance designs in reducing the respiratory event index (REI) in moderate and severe OSA patients who were dissatisfied with CPAP therapy.
results_summary: The abstract does not provide specific results regarding CPAP's effects, only noting that patients were dissatisfied with it. The study focused on comparing two OA designs rather than evaluating CPAP directly.
population_specificity: Moderate and severe adult OSA patients previously prescribed CPAP but dissatisfied with it.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether adding a weight-loss Mediterranean diet/lifestyle intervention to standard CPAP treatment improves obstructive sleep apnea (OSA) severity more than CPAP alone.
results_summary: The study found that combining CPAP with a Mediterranean diet/lifestyle intervention led to significantly greater reductions in OSA severity and symptoms compared to CPAP alone, with benefits independent of weight loss. The Mediterranean lifestyle group also showed improved sleep quality and reduced daytime sleepiness compared to the diet-only group.
population_specificity: Overweight adults (men and women) diagnosed with moderate-to-severe OSA (AHI ≥ 15 events/h).
effective_dosage: Not specified (CPAP settings not detailed in the abstract).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the association between Continuous Positive Airway Pressure (CPAP) and in-hospital mortality in COVID-19 patients with pneumonia.
results_summary: The study found that mechanical ventilation/CPAP was directly associated with increased in-hospital mortality (HR 2.726, 95% CI 1.823-4.074, P < 0.001), suggesting a negative outcome for CPAP use in this context. However, the study primarily focused on HCQ + azithromycin treatment effects, not CPAP's standalone efficacy.
population_specificity: 377 consecutive patients admitted for COVID-19-related pneumonia (mean age 71.8 ± 13.4 years, 34.2% women).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to identify risk factors for non-invasive/invasive ventilatory support (including CPAP) in COVID-19 patients.
results_summary: The study found that 31.5% of patients required CPAP, and independent risk factors for ventilatory support included elevated temperature, LDH, and d-dimer levels. CPAP was part of the oxygen therapy strategies but was not directly evaluated for efficacy or safety.
population_specificity: COVID-19 patients admitted to the Infectious Diseases Unit and ICU of Santa Maria Annunziata Hospital (Florence, Italy).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether a telemonitoring system could improve CPAP therapy adherence among Asian patients with moderate-to-severe obstructive sleep apnea (OSA).
results_summary: The telemonitoring group showed a non-significant trend toward higher CPAP usage hours, significantly better adherence rates, lower leakage, and improved sleep quality compared to usual care, though adverse events and daytime sleepiness reduction were similar between groups.
population_specificity: Asian adults (70% male) with moderate-to-severe OSA.
effective_dosage: Not specified (CPAP usage measured in hours/night).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether combination therapy (CPAP + OA) reduces therapeutic CPAP requirements in patients with an incomplete response to oral appliance therapy alone.
results_summary: The study recruited 16 incomplete responders to OA therapy (residual AHI > 10 events/h) to evaluate the effects of combining CPAP with a novel oral appliance. The abstract does not provide specific results on the extent of CPAP requirement reduction.
population_specificity: 16 incomplete responders to OA therapy (3 women, 13 men, aged 31-65 yr, BMI: 22-38 kg/m²).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review the impact of CPAP therapy on Alzheimer's disease biomarkers, cognitive function, and neurophysiology in individuals with obstructive sleep apnea (OSA).
results_summary: CPAP therapy shows potential in normalizing Alzheimer's disease biomarkers (e.g., amyloid-β and tau) in cerebrospinal fluid and improving cognitive domains like attention, particularly in middle-aged adults with severe OSA. However, evidence remains preliminary, and large longitudinal studies are lacking.
population_specificity: Individuals with obstructive sleep apnea (OSA), including younger and older adults, with varying severity of OSA and cognitive impairment.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess whether Continuous Positive Airway Pressure (CPAP) treatment reduces visceral adipose tissue (VAT) in patients with obstructive sleep apnea (OSA).
results_summary: The meta-analysis found no significant reduction in VAT after CPAP treatment in OSA patients, with subgroup analyses confirming no influence from therapy duration, age, sample size, or baseline BMI.
population_specificity: Patients with obstructive sleep apnea (OSA).
study_duration: Not specified (subgroup analysis considered duration but exact lengths not detailed)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effectiveness of bubble continuous positive airway pressure (bCPAP) versus nasal oxygen in treating respiratory distress in neonates, measured by the Silverman Anderson Retraction Score (SARS).
results_summary: bCPAP was significantly more effective than nasal oxygen, with 93.3% effectiveness in the bCPAP group compared to 71.7% in the control group (p = 0.003). The median reduction in SARS was also greater in the bCPAP group (4 vs. 3, p < 0.001).
population_specificity: Neonates with respiratory distress admitted to the Department of Paediatrics, Unit-1, KEMU/Mayo Hospital, Lahore, Pakistan.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the effect of CPAP therapy on MDA levels in patients with OSA using meta-analysis to resolve inconsistencies in previous findings.
results_summary: Pooled analysis showed CPAP therapy significantly reduced MDA levels, with subgroup analyses confirming effectiveness across age and BMI categories. The study concluded CPAP has a considerable effect on MDA, a marker linked to cardiovascular risk.
population_specificity: Patients with obstructive sleep apnea (OSA).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to analyze the association between risk-seeking behavior in the health/safety domain and CPAP discontinuation among OSA patients.
results_summary: The study found that risk-seeking patients were more likely to discontinue CPAP, and those with an AHI <30 also showed higher discontinuation rates. The DOSPERT scale was identified as a useful tool for screening such patients.
population_specificity: Consecutive OSA patients prescribed CPAP in a multicenter cohort.
